ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about elementary quarks, the fundamental forces, and many interesting theories/hypothesis.
Intro to concepts in Quantum Physics.
I learned some stuff about quantum physics.
Developed understanding of quantum physics
I really did learn a lot of the basics of quantum physics and how to speak about it in a well informed way with everyday individuals.

I learned about various ideas in quantum physics such as the Big Bang (lots of focus on the Big Bang!), light quanta, Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle, the double-slit experiment, entanglement, space-time/relative motion, and black holes.
I gained a basic understanding of the fundamentals of quantum physics (general and special relativity, black holes, the 4 forces, etc...).
Gave a strong background in Astro dinner conversation.
I learnt a lot about the basics of quantum physics, mainly from a theoretical standpoint as opposed to a mathematical one.
I learned a lot about conceptual quantum physics and could explain most topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Very accommodating professor and content was extremely interesting.
Weaknesses: Assignments were sometimes vague and it was hard to figure out how the marking happened/where I stood grades-wise

Professor Caines is great and very kind. The class is pretty well structure, but I thought it was harshly graded in a completely unnecessary and nit-picky way. The quizzes were also very hard to prepare for because a lot of the quiz content was not on any problem sets. I found that very frustrating and stressful.

This class is interesting but the fact that this is supposedly oriented towards non-STEM majors is a lie. There are significant physics concepts that, with no background in physics, make understanding lecture material extremely difficult. The TA grading the practice problems was often extremely unfair in grading, and the practice sets themselves often asked insane questions that are unanswerable.
Well taught, psets spaced out well and engaging

Strengths - very comprehensive, cool material 
Weaknesses - the grading on the psets was ridiculous.  Sometimes I felt like I was expected to volunteer details about complicated concepts that I would have had no way of knowing or understanding. The psets were very very long especially in the beginning of the course.

For a science credit this was a solid course - I learned about a bunch of ideas in quantum physics and the work was not too bad (class met once a week + homework took max 2-3 hours a week)! One thing I thought could be improved was the layout of the lecture slides/presentation of content - sometimes it was a little confusing how things were explained, and it could have been elucidated by making clearer connections between slides/topics. One other weakness was that points were taken off on homework assignments (mine and other people commented on this as well) for minute details/things that were barely covered in the reading.

The material is very interesting, but ultimately falls flat because of the format of the course. It would be better as a twice a week, shorter lecture. I think the grading of the homework assignments could also be a lot better. Since we're graded on our understanding of material before we've even learned it in class, grading felt much more luck of the draw (did I happen to guess all the points that were included on the answer key even when questions didn't specifically ask about them) as opposed to a reflection of how much effort I put into any specific assignment. It would be better if readings were assigned before class and then homework assignments were due at the end of the day after class. That way, we'd still be familiar with the material before class, and we'd be graded on actual comprehension.
Really really liked the breadth.

Strengths - it was nice that it was a small ish class, and the Professor was clearly interested in the content. It was also a good introduction to many topics. I liked the marking scheme as it didnt rely on just exams or just weekly homework. 

Weaknesses - the psets were often marked arbitrarily, and points deducted according to a very specific marking scheme. I think the students who had some knowledge of quantum physics benefitted a lot more. The level of detail we learnt about each topic varied.
Clear topics and it never gets too complicated in the science aspect.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes -  it's a great way to learn these advanced concepts in physics even if you are not a STEM major.
If you're a non STEM major looking for a science credit, I would not recommend this class. The material felt useless and it was stressful and hard.
As long as you have some physics background, this class isn't that bad. Just be prepared to be confused consistently.
Yes - good science credit and interesting course
no
For a science credit and/or an easy, pretty low-stress intro to quantum physics, yes.

I really wanted to like this course because it sounded amazing, but at the end of the day no. It's really not a gut in terms of workload/grading, and the format of the course isn't conducive to gaining a strong understanding of the concepts.
Definitely. Great class. Not really a gut in terms of there is quite a bit of work.
I would recommend it if you genuinely have any sort of interest in the subject. Its really though provoking. I dont think youd get a lot out of it otherwise, its not really a gut!
Yes if you're looking for a gut science.
